question: Three card brag is a simple form of poker; you are dealt only three cards and these you can't change. If you don't look at your cards you're a `blind man' and you only put in half the stake. Three of any kind is the highest you can get I haven't slept for forty-eight hours, got a dozen broken ribs, can feel a case of the flu coming on and . . . If you think you're in the dark, I am in a black hole, blindfolded.
answer: See these goods, they never seen daylight, moonlight, Israelite, Fanny- by-the-gas-light. If you can't see value here today you're not up here shopping, you're up here shoplifting. Take a bag, take a bag. I took a bag, I took a bag home last night and she cost a lot more than ten pounds I can tell ya. Tell me if I am going too cheap. Not ninety, not eighty, not forty, half that and half that again, that's right, ten pounds. Don't think 'cos it's sealed up it's an empty box. The only man who sells empty boxes is the undertaker, and by the look of some of you here today I would make more money with me measuring tape.

question: Bargain, that's a bloody bargain if I ever heard one. Ten pounds you say? I'll have five.
answer: Excuse me misses, sorry sir, ladies first and all that.

question: Bacon!
answer: Ed can run fast, talk fast, eat fast, and play cards fast, but he's fucking slow when it comes to spotting the roz.

question: Please, both join me in my orifice.
answer: How much did you say it was, Tom?

question: You know how much it is, Nick.
answer: And that does include the amp?

question: You know it doesn't include the amp. What have you come as?
answer: Cupid stupid! That's the last time I am getting any more fruit off you Tom. Call that fresh? There was more small hairy armoured things in your fruit than there was fruit. You should open a butcher's, not a grocer's.

question: If you will order stuff that comes from Kat-Man-Fucking-Du don't be surprised if your fruit picks up a few tourists en route. ~ Never mind that, what about the money?
answer: Get your fingers out of my soup!

question: EDDY been shaking the knees of a lot of good players. The boy has a rare ability, he seems to make cards transparent, got bluffing dow . .
answer: All right, all right, so we can say he is good.

question: Better than good, he is a fucking liability.
answer: Where did he get a hundred grand?

question: He has got some adhesive mates, they have tossed up between them.
answer: And JD is his dad, and owns the whole property?

question: No mortgage, no debts; lock, stock, the sodding lot . . . don't worry, I got it under control.
answer: Good, you can get this under control now.

question: Er, very nice Harry. What's it for?
answer: Don't play innocent with me Bazza; spanking!

question: So, a reasonable return should be in the region of one hundred and twenty, for twenty-five grand invested. That's going on previous experiences.
answer: That's going on optimism.

question: Whatever it's going on, it's still enough to send you on a cooking course.
answer: You're not funny Tom; you're fat and look as though you should be funny, but you're not.

question: How long has he been in there, son?
answer: About twenty minutes.

question: Is he on his own?
answer: Just carrying a bag.

question: Let's have a look, shall we? Son, have a look under that one.
answer: It's not him, Dad.

question: Try that one.
answer: Sleeping like a baby.

question: This is one of those high-powered numbers, isn't it?
answer: What the fu-!

question: Mind your language in front of my boy.
answer: Jesus Christ!

question: He said shut it!
answer: Tell Harry . . .

question: Did I say speak? And it's Mr Harry to you . . . Now don't disappoint me and chose your words carefully. You may speak.
answer: I'll have it for Mr Harry in a few days. I have been busy, and I am nearly there.

question: Son, have a look in his locker.
answer: No chance of you lifting this sunbed up is there?

question: Give me a hand Charlie, I could break sweat at any second.
answer: Charles, why have we got this cage? That's right, for security. So tell me, Charles, what's the point in having it if we don't fucking use it? Yes Charlie, but you didn't know it was Willy, did you?

question: Chill, Winston, it's me and Charlie can see it's me, so what's the problem?
answer: The problem is, Willy, that Charlie and yourself are not the quickest of cats in the alley at the best of times, so just do as I say and keep the fucking cage locked. What are you carrying, Willy?

question: Er, fertilizer.
answer: You went out six hours ago to buy a money counter and you come back carrying two bags of fertilizer. Alarm bells are ringing, Willy.

question: We need fertilizer, Winston.
answer: We also need a fucking money counter, William! We have to get the money out by Thursday and I'll be buggered if I am counting it . . . and if you have to get your sodding fertilizer, couldn't you be a little more subtle?

question: What do you mean?
answer: I mean we grow copious amounts of ganja, and you don't look like your average hort-er-fucking-culturalist, that's what I mean, Willy.

question: It's a fucking stately home, of course there'll be something there.
answer: Like what?

question: Like antiques.
answer: Antiques? What the fuck do we know about antiques? We rob post offices and steal cars, what the fuck do we know about antiques?

question: If it looks old, it's worth money, simple. So stop fucking moaning and rob the place.
answer: So who's the Guv? Who we doing this for?

question: You're doing it for me is all you need to know. You only know that because you need to know.
answer: I see, one of those `on a need to know' basis things, like a James Bond film, is it?

question: Careful, remember who's giving you this job.
answer: I hate these Southern shites.

question: A Samoan one. Anything else?
answer: What's that?

question: A cocktail, you asked for a cocktail.
answer: No, I asked you to give me a refreshing drink. I wasn't expecting a fucking rainforest; you could fall in love with an orang-utan in that.

question: You want a pint, go to the pub.
answer: I thought this was a pub.

question: It's a Samoan pub.
answer: Well whatever it is, could you get your man to turn the TV down?

question: You ask him if you like, but I would leave him to it if I was you.
answer: Excuse me, could you turn the TV down?

question: What?
answer: I thought you said no staff, Bazza!

question: You get the guns?
answer: You should see what they did to poor Gary. Gary, get back into the van!

question: Good. I'll speak to you later.
answer: Gary, Gary, if you can hear me, I think we better get you back in the van now, OK?

question: Twenty thousand open.
answer: Got some cards there, boy? Thirty thousand. Back to you already Eddy?

question: Fifty grand.
answer: Eighty grand.

question: That is quite a raise, one hundred and fifty on my hundred.
answer: Yes . . . and is there something else you want to say? EDDY I will.

question: You will what?
answer: I will loan you the money.

question: I think I would rather just turn them over.
answer: I am not interested in what you would rather; I want to keep going. I am also offering you the money, so we don't have to turn them over because you can borrow.

question: I need two hundred and fifty grand.
answer: No, you need five hundred grand to see me.

question: That's if I want to see you.
answer: Well, you're going to have a problem carrying on, aintcha.

question: I'll see ya.
answer: For half a million?

question: Unless you are going to accept twenty quid.
answer: And still got a sense of humour. That's not monkey nuts son; you can still fold. OK, before I loan you this, I expect, if you lose of course, my money back within a week, Crystal? That's Sunday, OK?

question: Use that cage, that's what it's there for.
answer: Plank, open up.

question: What do you think?
answer: Fuck me! Sorry fellas, but that stupid cow!

question: Anyway, how much do you want?
answer: I am after a half weight.

question: The odds are one hundred to one so all we need is five grand.
answer: I would rather put my money on a three-legged rocking horse. The odds are a hundred to one for a good reason, BACON . . . it won't win. So where is Ed with all the bright ideas?

question: At the bottom of a bottle and has been for two days; it's hit him hard.
answer: It's hit us all hard!

question: Yeah, but he has got to tell his Dad he is about to lose his bar.
answer: Listen to this one then; you open a company called the Arse Tickler's Faggot Fan Club. You take an advert in the back page of some gay mag, advertising the latest in arse-intruding dildos, sell it a bit with, er . . . I dunno, `does what no other dildo can do until now', latest and greatest in sexual technology. Guaranteed results or money back, all that bollocks. These dills cost twenty-five each; a snip for all the pleasure they are going to give the recipients. They send a cheque to the company name, nothing offensive, er, Bobbie's Bits or something, for twenty-five. You put these in the bank for two weeks and let them clear. Now this is the clever bit. Then you send back the cheques for twenty-five pounds from the real company name, Arse Tickler's Faggot Fan Club, saying sorry, we couldn't get the supply from America, they have sold out. Now you see how many of the people cash those cheques; not a single soul, because who wants his bank manager to know he tickles arses when he is not paying in cheques!

question: So how long do you have to wait 'till you see a return?
answer: Probably no longer than four weeks.

question: A month? So, my friend, what fucking good is that, if we need it in six . . . no, five days?
answer: Well, it's still a good idea.

question: Listen, they can't be all stupid if they got a container load of cash sitting in shoe boxes, a skip-load of Class A gear and you don't think there is anybody sensible involved. What about security?
answer: There's one steel gate as you go in but they never lock it.

question: What do you mean, never? Well what have they got it for, then?
answer: I must have been there fifty times, it's never been locked; they're not suspicious. Everybody who goes there are toffs. They're all into that karma crap

question: Is there no way they can get back to you?
answer: Even if they could they'd be too shit scared. They have got no muscle; they're gutless faggots.

question: Oi, watch it! No thanks Harry, we are both all right. Nice shooter.
answer: Like it? One of a pair, Holland and Holland. Here, you want to hold it?

question: Nah, not my thing, thank you, Harry. Business good? I imagine that's what I am here for.
answer: I want you to forget about any other debts at the moment; there are fresher fish to fry!

question: Go on.
answer: It's a bit of a priority. Four young fellas who got in deeper than they could handle; they owe me half a million pounds.

question: Well, we hit them as soon as they come back. We'll be waiting and prepared for them.
answer: What was that, armed? What do you mean, armed? Armed with what?

question: Er, bad breath, colourful language and a feather duster! . . . What do you think they will be armed with? Guns, you tit!
answer: Guns! You never said anything about guns. A minute ago this was the safest job in the world, now it's turning in to a bad day in Bosnia . .

question: Jesus, Soap, stop being such a mincer. I thought about that and...
answer: And what exactly?

question: And we will just have to find out who's going to be carrying them.
answer: Carrying them. They could all be carrying them for what we know.

question: No, just one of them is in charge of them going to the job. So I assume he will still
answer: Oh, you assume, do ya? What do they say about assumption being the brother of all fuck-ups?

question: Weed?
answer: Not normal weed. This is some fucked-up skunk class A. I can't think let alone move shit.

question: Doesn't sound very good to me.
answer: Neither me, but it depends on what flicks your switch, and the light's on and burning bright for the masses.

question: You'll need samples, Tom.
answer: No can do.

question: Where's that? A place near Katmandu? Meet me half way, mate.
answer: Listen, it's all completely chicken soup.

question: It's what?
answer: Kosher as Christmas

question: Jews don't celebrate Christmas, Tom.
answer: Never mind that now. I also need some artillery, you know, a couple of sawn-off shotguns.

question: Bloody hell, Tom! This is a bit heavy. This is London, not the Lebanon' Who do you think I am?
answer: I think you're Nick the Greek.

question: Is your hair supposed to look like that, then?
answer: Next time we do a job like this we gonna want more money, or we are going back to post offices and cars.

question: Where're the others?
answer: There are no others.

question: Now, stop fucking around. The others, the old ones?
answer: I don't know what you mean.

question: There were two old guns there; where are they?
answer: Not in the cabinet there wasn't. There was a couple of old hammer-lock muskets the butler was carrying; they were ours, and we sold 'em!

question: Well you just better un-sell 'em, sharpish.
answer: They were . . .

question: Jesus, if I pick them up, will they stay in one piece? Where did you get them from?
answer: I got contacts. Listen Tom, if you pointed them at me I'd shit myself or do whatever you said to do. Either way you still get the desired effect.

question: They look nice, I agree . . . but lacking in criminal credibility, aren't they? I might get laughed at. How much do you want for these muskets?
answer: Seven hundred each.

question: What's that, a pound for every year they have been around? I know they're antiques, but I ain't paying antique prices. Pause.
answer: Sawn-offs are out, Tom; people like to have a bit mare range nowadays.

question: Range? I don't want to blow the arse out of this country, granted, but I don't want anybody blowing a raspberry at me either. I want to look fucking mean.
answer: Of course you will look mean, Tom, you will look really scary.

question: All right, let's forget about them for the time being. What about your weed man?
answer: Rory Breaker is standing by. You stand to make a lot of money, Tommy boy.

question: I understand if this has come as a bit of a shock, but I'll tell you how this can be resolved by the good father.
answer: Go on.

question: I like your bar.
answer: Yes?

question: I want your bar.
answer: And?

question: Do you want me to draw a picture?
answer: Harry, that boy doesn't know his arsehole from his ear-hole, or you from a hoodwink. This bar is mine, and he has nothing to do with it.

question: What, and I care? Remember, you do have the luxurious advantage of being able to sustain your son's life.
answer: And you do have a reputation, so I'll choose my words carefully. But not to put too fine a point on it, fuck yourself, Harry!

question: No, you silly fucker, stay still. What's going on?
answer: Come on, I can't wait out here all day. I thought you were going to leave me out there all day. Lives and learns doesn't one. I know. Now shut it. You say a fucking word the right knee goes, another word then your left. What do you think I am doing? Hold on. What are you doing? Unlock that gate. Oi! I said unlock that fucking gate.

question: Go! Go! Go! Fucking run, you two. (mesmerized} The fucking gate's shut, you prick.
answer: Just hold on, I got the keys.

question: What the fuck did you do to Fauntleroy?
answer: I didn't touch him, he just passed out.

question: You could have brought something a bit more fucking practical, couldn't ya?
answer: Don't you stags move or I'll kill the lot of ya.

question: Who are you going to kill Plank? There's no one there.
answer: They shot me!

question: If you use that again, you're a dead man, do you understand?
answer: Well, J will certainly get it if we don't; he's serious. Look what he did to his toes.

question: Right, his leg's going now.
answer: All right, all fucking right, I am coming. Willie, he doesn't know you are here, just sort something out, OK.

question: And all your friends, there's a good lad.
answer: There is only three of us here.

question: Do you want me to take his leg off? Where's the fourth?
answer: I mean it, there is only three of us here.

question: Plank?
answer: Yeah, one of them's out.

question: OK, open the gate.
answer: There, in those shoe boxes.

question: Out the back.
answer: Point.

question: With what?
answer: Your hands, now!

question: I can't, I am tied up.
answer: Well, well, shake your head or something.

question: You got a ticket already and, if you don't move it now, sir, we will move it for you.
answer: I'll only be a minute.

question: You've already been fifteen.
answer: Look. Go on, look.

question: At what, exactly?
answer: My van is half full.

question: So?
answer: So I've just got to put you in, and I am off.

question: Where the hell are we supposed to hide?
answer: What are you doing, Ed?

question: Do you want one?
answer: No I fucking don't! You can't make a cup of tea, Edward.

question: Why not? The whole of the British Empire was built on cups of tea.
answer: And look what happened to that.

question: Paul, what's that?
answer: That's a traffic warden.

question: What's he doing in the van?
answer: He was about to call the cozzers.

question: Let's have a butcher's. Jesus, there's lots of everything. We've got god knows how much of this stinking weed; we've got a shit load of cash; and we've got a . . . traffic warden.
answer: A what?

question: A traffic warden. Look, what's this?
answer: Shit Ed, we've got a traffic warden.

question: (proudly j We shot one of them in the throat.
answer: What do you want, a fucking medal? I'll shoot you in the fucking throat if I don't get the gear back.

question: No, another one.
answer: This is more like it. So where's he?

question: They took him with them; he was still alive.
answer: Well, what did you shoot him with, an air gun?

question: We grow weed, we're not mercenaries.
answer: You don't say.

question: Your one saving grace might be your stupidity.
answer: Er.

question: Don't fucking er me, Greek boy! How is it that your so-fucking-stupid, soon-to-be-dead friends thought they might be able to steal my gear? And then sell it back to me? Is this a declaration of war? Is this some sort of white cunts' joke that black cunts don't get? 'Cos I am not fucking laughing, Nik-ol-as.
answer: Er.

question: Yeah?
answer: That's no way to answer the phone.

question: Is that you, Dean?
answer: Sure is.

question: What can I do for you?
answer: You know those shotguns I sold ya, well I need 'em back.

question: Not likely I am afraid; I don't think I'll be seeing them again.
answer: I got the money to pay for 'em.

question: I am sure you do, but I don't think you understand; I am not going to see them or the guns again.
answer: If we can't get 'em, we can't get 'em.

question: If we can't get 'em, we can't get 'em.
answer: You fucking well have to get 'em!

question: We made a deal for everything inside the cabinet.
answer: Inside, out-fuckin'-side. I don't give a shit, you get those guns because if you don't . . .

question: Yeah, Bazza, what?
answer: You heard of Harry Lonsdale? Otherwise known as Back-you-up with-a- Hatchet Harry, infamous for his removal of digits?

question: Dog, I have found the cash!
answer: The stupid bastards! Count it!

question: Shit, Dog, there's a lot. Don't you want to do this next door?
answer: We're not going next door until we've flayed these dead men walking. Count it out the back. I don't want them seeing you fingering that money as soon as they walk in.

question: There's six black cocks sitting on the side of the road. How many beaks have they got between them?
answer: Six.

question: How many wings have they got between them?
answer: Twelve.

question: How many feet?
answer: Er, well, twelve.

question: That's right. So how many whiskers has the little white kitten got?
answer: How the fuck should I know?

question: Well, not especially, but they seem to of upset a few characters.
answer: Have you counted the money?

question: Yeah, it's all there, to the pound.
answer: They were going to pay, then?

question: It looks like ?, but who knows? The opportunity was there. In my experience it is best to take the opportunity if it is there.
answer: Good job, Chris.

question: That you, boy?
answer: It's Ed, if that's what you mean.

question: It's pay day, ain't it?
answer: I wanted to talk to you about that.

question: You and me, Tom.
answer: What do you mean, me? That's it, I am off.

question: Tom, this is our case.
answer: . . . What?

question: This is our money, Tom! . . . Now I think we should go.
answer: I'll meet you in the car. I am taking these guns.

question: Tom, don't mess around, let's go.
answer: I'11 meet you in the car.

question: Tom?
answer: I'll only be a minute.

question: A job well done son; we made a few quid out of that one. Son?
answer: Made a few quid, did ya? Now where is it?

question: You all right back there, mate?
answer: Very fucking funny. Where's what I want?

question: It's in an office; I have just left it in the office. 137
answer: Well, you had better go and get it from the office. That's if you want to see your son reach his next birthday. Now chop-fuckin'-chop.

question: All right, furry muff.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Well, it's a five minute walk or a thirty second drive.
answer: You had better be careful.

question: Chris. You come to collect something, Chris? Should I have something for you?
answer: Nope.

question: Can I help?
answer: I think I can help you, as it happens.

question: Yes?
answer: I have got something for ya. Well, for your boy, actually.

question: Well, I suggest you speak to him, then.
answer: It seems that Hatchet under-estimated your lot and that seems to have cost him . . . I am not going to make the same mistake, am I? I have decided to bring your bag back.
